trans-unit.source: All arithmetic input values are based on Numeric Literals to represent numerical values of the CLR System.Double type.
trans-unit.target: All arithmetic input values are based on Numeric Literals to represent numerical values of the CLR System.Double type.

trans-unit.source: The following examples demonstrate the supported numerical literals:
trans-unit.target: The following examples demonstrate the supported numerical literals:

trans-unit.source: The <token>transform</token> parser does not support suffixes that indicate the data type of a numeric literal.
trans-unit.target: The <token>transform</token> parser does not support suffixes that indicate the data type of a numeric literal.

trans-unit.source: For example, using 2L to be represented as Long is not supported.
trans-unit.target: For example, using 2L to be represented as Long is not supported.

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Double.TryParse()</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=228961</linkUri></externalLink> method is used to verify that a numeric literal value is a valid double value.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Double.TryParse()</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=228961</linkUri></externalLink> method is used to verify that a numeric literal value is a valid double value.

trans-unit.source: If it is not a valid double value, the argument is converted to a double using the <externalLink><linkText>Convert.ToDouble()</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=228962</linkUri></externalLink> method.
trans-unit.target: If it is not a valid double value, the argument is converted to a double using the <externalLink><linkText>Convert.ToDouble()</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=228962</linkUri></externalLink> method.

trans-unit.source: If the conversion fails, the value is zero.
trans-unit.target: If the conversion fails, the value is zero.

trans-unit.source: If an arithmetic expression has more than one operator, then <legacyBold>multiplication</legacyBold>, <legacyBold>division</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>modulo</legacyBold> are evaluated first.
trans-unit.target: If an arithmetic expression has more than one operator, then <legacyBold>multiplication</legacyBold>, <legacyBold>division</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>modulo</legacyBold> are evaluated first.

trans-unit.source: Then, addition and subtraction are evaluated.
trans-unit.target: Then, addition and subtraction are evaluated.

trans-unit.source: Use parenthesis to control the order.
trans-unit.target: Use parenthesis to control the order.

trans-unit.source: For example, adding or subtracting input values within parenthesis allows this part of the expression to be evaluated first.
trans-unit.target: For example, adding or subtracting input values within parenthesis allows this part of the expression to be evaluated first.

trans-unit.source: Numeric Values are not rounded unless Round is specifically used.
trans-unit.target: Numeric Values are not rounded unless Round is specifically used.

trans-unit.source: Requires at least one argument that is converted to double and an optional second argument that must be a non-negative integer.
trans-unit.target: Requires at least one argument that is converted to double and an optional second argument that must be a non-negative integer.

trans-unit.source: If the conversion fails, zero is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the conversion fails, zero is returned.

trans-unit.source: If the second argument is not provided, then the first argument is rounded to the nearest integer.
trans-unit.target: If the second argument is not provided, then the first argument is rounded to the nearest integer.

trans-unit.source: If the second argument is a positive integer, then the first argument is rounded to number of digits specified in the second argument.
trans-unit.target: If the second argument is a positive integer, then the first argument is rounded to number of digits specified in the second argument.

trans-unit.source: The maximum number of digits to round is 15.
trans-unit.target: The maximum number of digits to round is 15.

trans-unit.source: Higher values for the second argument will still result in rounding to 15 places.
trans-unit.target: Higher values for the second argument will still result in rounding to 15 places.

trans-unit.source: If the second argument cannot be converted to a non-negative integer, zero is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the second argument cannot be converted to a non-negative integer, zero is returned.

trans-unit.source: If an error occurs with an <ui>Arithmetic Expression</ui> <token>mapop</token>, by default, the entire <token>transform</token> is aborted.

trans-unit.source: This error handling behavior is configurable.
